Award.AwardTitle: Life-cycle Assessment of Resiliency and Sustainability of Buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A typical building must be in use for decades before the energy expended in its daily operations surpasses the energy embodied within its initial construction. Thus, how a sustainable building is constructed is as important as how it is operated over its lifetime. Unfortunately, the environmental impact of building construction has only recently been considered by design consultants, quantified by the energy expended in the manufacture of the materials employed. By considering only the materials' 'cradle' and not the 'cradle-to-grave' environmental impact, these evaluations fail to quantify the true impact of US building construction practices. In addition, each building has specific vulnerabilities, whose implications for sustainability has not been previously considered, despite the significant environmental impact of repairs after a disaster. This project will develop an integrated life-cycle analysis that responds to the complex relationship between sustainability and resilience. This research will help the US building industry realize designs with truly optimal performance. Doing so will advance the global mandate to reduce environmental impact and better steward of natural resources. Moreover, this project's adoption of established modeling environments, real world case studies, and private sector partnerships will aid in the effective translation to US design practice. The project's educational crossover opportunities will ensure that future design professionals are well equipped to further this legacy by using the outcomes of this research to enhance resilience and sustainability of our built environment.

This project will develop an integrated life-cycle assessment capturing the dependencies between multi-hazard resilience and sustainability, across the multiple contributing dimensions of environmental impact. The computationally efficient assessment will take advantage of (i) simulation-driven approaches, (ii) sample-based tools, (iii) soft-computing techniques, and (iv) new environmental impact toolsets that will mine publically available data to quantify the building's operational and embodied energy. Through sensitivity analyses on actual buildings, the framework will reveal which design aspects truly drive environmental impact and how this is affected by the consideration of lifetime exposure. The transfer of this newfound understanding is further facilitated by engaging practicing engineers and architects directly in the research effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A typical building must be in use for decades before the energy expended in its daily operations surpasses the energy embodied within its initial construction. Thus, how a ?sustainable? building is constructed is as important as how it is operated over its lifetime. Unfortunately, the many dimensions of environmental impact, including the energy embodied in building materials, have only recently been considered by design firms. These considerations generally focus only the materials? ?cradle? and not the ?cradle-to-grave? environmental impact. As such, they often fail to quantify the true impact of US construction practices, particularly during the conceptual design stage when critical decisions are made. More concerning is the fact that each building has specific vulnerabilities, whose implications for sustainability over the full life cycle have not been previously considered, despite the significant environmental impact of repairs after a disaster. In response, this project developed the first integrated life cycle assessment (iLCA) that preserves this complex relationship between sustainability and hazard resilience. Moreover, this project sped the adoption of this new iLCA into practice by using established modeling environments like Revit and SAP, real-world case studies using popular building systems, and partnerships with two of the nation?s leading design firms. By providing designers with a holistic assessment of a building?s resilience and sustainability even as the design is conceptualized, a number of important impacts can be realized: (1) greater safety and security from the impacts of natural hazards, (2) better stewardship of natural resources by reducing the energy consumed and embodied by buildings, and (3) more cost-effective buildings with reduced repair costs, downtime and operational energy demands. 

The workflow for integrated life-cycle assessment was developed by an interdisciplinary team of architects, structural engineers, and computer scientists, including graduate and undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in engineering and science. This team connected a series of modules that (i) extract critical building information, (ii) characterize the hazards and climate at the building site, (iii) analyze the building response to these hazards, (iv) project resulting damages to the building, and (v) calculate repair costs, operating energy demands, and embodied energy levels, all using industry-standard software and leveraging the power of linked open data. By capturing the dependencies between multi-hazard resilience and sustainability, real-world case studies from this project revealed which components drive the performance of common commercial building systems in earthquake and hurricane zones. These case studies further demonstrated how the iLCA can determine when it is actually more effective to upgrade the primary structure and reduce the demands on these components, instead of updating specific components such as window systems experiencing the greatest losses. Ironically, these case studies also suggested that building envelope products recognized for energy efficiency may actually have higher initial embodied energy and require more repairs due to damage over the service life, which ultimately results in an overall greater embodied energy and thus greater environmental impact. Other case studies demonstrated the value of equipping architects with an iLCA during the conceptual design process when floor plan decisions are made, as the absence of any such analysis prevents teams from exploring the implications of these decisions on performance, especially under strong winds. Thus, this project not only affirmed that resilience and sustainability are inseparable in the building design process, but also delivered the tools that make these analyses finally possible.
